docs.lead_paragraph: How does a brainy vice president of a marketing agency in Manhattan end up marrying a graduate of the Ringling Brothers and Barnum & Bailey Clown College? Blame the Internet.
docs.snippet: How does a brainy vice president of a marketing agency in Manhattan end up marrying a graduate of the Ringling Brothers and Barnum & Bailey Clown College? Blame the Internet.

docs.lead_paragraph: MARC JACOBS Whether he's toying with editors by dyeing his hair blue or by starting his notoriously late shows right on time (as he did for fall), the designer Marc Jacobs is no stranger to controversy. In fact, he finds a certain kinship with the gutsy women he designs for, such as the French actress Élodie Bouchez, whom he styled and palled around with for ''Stork Club'' on Page 70. ''She's the kind of girl I relate to on a lot of different levels,'' he says. Having worked with everyone from Dakota Fanning to the artist Richard Prince (his ''Danger Nurse at Work'' is at center), Jacobs is something of a pop-culture buff. ''I just kind of like the cartoony aspect of life today as seen through the media,'' he says. So why did he decide on the madcap idea of his underwear-as-outerwear collection for spring (far right)? ''I don't know, maybe it's because of the news of Britney and all this other stuff,'' he says. Oops, he did it again.

docs.lead_paragraph: UPDATED | 11:46 AM If you've got AIDS, cancer or erectile dysfunction a group of big advertising networks are going to promise not to remember that you read sites about those topics and remind you (or others using your computer) of your condition with ads for related drugs as you surf the net.

headline.main: Ad Industry Bans Targeting People With Cancer; Ads to Widows and Orphans Allowed

docs.abstract: A group of advertising companies is proposing restrictions on monitoring users' Web surfing on some sensitive topics. Cancer and sexual orientation are on the list. It said targeting ads based on "political affiliation" or "death" is sometimes acceptable.

docs.lead_paragraph: The tendency to have a breech delivery is inherited, a new study reports, and it is apparently inherited equally through the father and the mother.
